author: cbc
title: Police seeking man who may have info on Paradise home invasion
text:
Police say the man they're looking for in Paradise may have information connected to a home invasion Thursday.
On Monday afternoon, the Royal Newfoundland Constabulary announced it was seeking the public's help finding missing person Mohamed Salim, 28.
Sources have told CBC News that Salim is a suspect in the incident, but police have not confirmed that. The RNC's statement said only that investigators believe Salim may have information that could help with the investigation.
Monday is the third day officials were on the scene, following investigative efforts on Friday and Sunday night.
Rovers searchers were walking around the edges of Topsail Round Pond in the morning, before a helicopter touched down on Three Island Pond.
Helicopter lands in Paradise as part of home invasion investigation 1:28
Meanwhile, a suspect in Thursday's Paradise home invasion was convicted for manslaughter in a fatal Toronto jailhouse beating in 2010, CBC News has learned.
Abdifatah Mohamed, who is charged with forcible confinement and break and entry in the Paradise incident, was described in a written decision by an Ontario court justice as the leader of the 2010 jailhouse attack against Kevon Phillip.
Abdifatah Mohamed appears in court in St. John's on Friday. (Ted Dillon/CBC)
Phillip was attacked in a common area of Toronto's Don Jail by a group of men, who then dragged him to a cell and beat him for about 20 minutes, according to the ruling.
Witnesses told the Toronto court that Mohamed was directing parts of the process, including telling the group of inmates to bring Phillip into the cell, and directing prisoners to cover the entrance to the cell and to clean up the scene following the beating.
According to the Toronto Star , a judge found that the men, including Mohamed, did not mean to kill Phillip, and said that the group tried to alter the cell to make it appear Phillip died in his sleep.
Mohamed was sentenced to eight years for his role in the attack. With credit for time served, he was due to have been released within three years and three months after the sentencing.
Suspects appear in court One person was held against their will by Mohamed and another armed intruder during Thursday's home invasion, according to police.
Violent Paradise home invasion suspects paraded through court The Royal Newfoundland Constabulary said those two men, Tyler Donahue and Mohamed, were part of a group of four who were arrested following a violent break and enter and robbery on Angel's Road.
The Rovers search and rescue team is back on scene Monday near Dawes Road in Paradise, close to where a home invasion happened Thursday night. (Garrett Barry/CBC)
All four appeared in provincial court on Monday.
Donahue, 23, and Mohamed, 27, have been charged with forcible confinement, unlawful possession of a firearm, as well as robbery and break and entry.
Mitchell Nippard, 25, and Gary Thomas Hennessey, 32, face charges of break and enter.
The group will remain in custody until their next appearance on March 3.
Police on scene say it is a continuation of the investigation into Thursday night's home invasion. #cbcnl #nlcrime pic.twitter.com/i7XNZsw1yw
â€” @GarrettBarry In court on Monday, Nippard asked to plead not guilty, and said he was innocent.
"I shouldn't be incarcerated," he said.
"I have a right to a speedy trial. I didn't do this offence."
With files from Garrett Barry and Rob Antle
